critique: This executive order concerns the administration of disability retirement pay and hospitalization for members and former members of the uniformed services. It shifts some duties related to hospitalization for chronic diseases to the Administrator of Veterans' Affairs, while retaining some responsibilities with the Secretary concerned, especially for those with longer active duty. There's no clear indication of ideological tilt, immigration policy, or impacts on civil liberties. It seems to be primarily an administrative reorganization within the government. It doesn't obviously expand executive power, but rather clarifies the roles of different agencies. It doesn't directly address economic regulation or social inclusion. The federalism aspect is somewhat relevant as it divides responsibilities between federal entities (Veterans' Affairs and the Secretary concerned).
